This is one of the foodie things that makes this city so fantastic.  A truck, that is always in a different location serving hot waffles with the best toppings Mom wouldn't let you use as a kid Sunday morning...is this heaven?!  Is there any way to say no to a warm waffle with some Nutella, bacon and Belgian chocolate drizzled on top (no there absolutely isn't, and if you disagree stop reading my review, you're dead to me).  Besides the main truck there are smaller carts all over, which sadly have less topping options, meaning no bacon, but are still enough to make my mouth water.  This really is one of the fun quirky things NYC has to offer and everyone should try!  P.S. While the Union Square Holiday fair is going on there is always a Waffle stand...get to it!

It's a good day when you are eating a bacon waffle for dinner. It also doesn't hurt when the waffle man is friendly and gives you a dollar off the obscenely high price of $6. I like this truck. I like the Euro-sounding name. I like that they use real maple syrup. I like that when I asked, I got a fresh waffle, instead of one that had been sitting around. I like the chalk board on the side with its question of the day ("what art did you see on the museum mile?" or "what movies should they show in bryant park next summer?"). I like that they call their waffles WMDs ("wafel of mass deliciousness"). The only thing that I don't like is the price. :( Also-- more bacon please!!

I know that this may seem blasphemy but I had the pork wafel sandwich and it didn't taste very good.  The wafel was soggy and it didn't work with the other ingredients, i.e., the pork, pickle and cole slaw.

I am addicted to these wafels and I take all of my friends to this truck, they all fall in love with it as well.I prefer the brussels wafel, I've had it with a variety of toppings but usually I have it with spekuloos, strawberries, ice cream and whipped cream.  If you only try one topping, pick the spekuloos...it's amazing.

YUM-fest 2007.The Wafels & Dinges gentlemen sat outside of my bf's holiday party last Thursday evening and I was smart enough to go outside and see what the fuss was about.  A light n' crunchy waffle covered with chocolate, strawberries, and powdered sugar later, I was sold.  I want the W&D dudes to come cater my birthday, my Mom's birthday, and dessert every day from here on out.  Hunt this truck down and treat yourself.  They also sell their waffle mixes so you can try to replicate the awesomeness at home.
My favorite throwdown waffle comes in a mini size for only $3.00!!

I found myself in Union Square craving Wafels & Dinges... BADLY. They had a cute stand at the holiday market (which for some reason took forever to find, but it was really just on the outside of the market) and a nice, interactive (is that even the right word) guy took our order. I had a bite of my cousin's waffle with the speculoos spread a few weeks ago and it was the most amazing thing in the world, so I definitely had to try that. The guy said that bananas went well with the spread so I got it. And then I added some whipped cream and fudge just because I had 1 free dinge from the daily challenge (remember to check out their twitter for a daily challenge! I got the answer wrong but they gave it to me anyway). I was staring at the waffle as I tried to find a place to eat it. It took me probably 5 minutes or less to gobble it down because it was so delicious, but I don't know... it was one of those things where I really regret eating afterwards. It's way too sweet for me. I think it's the spread that is really too sweet. I would love it more if I split it with other people, because now I don't feel too great from how sweet it is. But I don't know, my excuse is that I'm Asian, so I can't deal with super sweet things as well. But the waffle was crunchy on the sides and I thought the speculoos spread was the perfect mix with that crunchiness - it was like biting into solid caramel in my mouth mmmm. I would probably go again... but this is definitely one of those places where I want to go super badly and then regret it after I eat a waffle. So I'm not sure how to rate this... I would give it a 3.5 but I can't. I'll just give it a 4, since maybe me regretting eating it because of how fat and full I feel now is a good sign?

The Liege waffle reminded me that some desserts can be eaten plain and still be delicious. My slightly warm and crispy waffle with powdered sugar from Wafels and Dinges had me from the first bite to the last. I can't imagine what this would taste like with toppings, and I'm not sure I even need to add any. The servers are so nice and I think their free topping promotions are a fun way for me to brush up on random Belgian facts.

I've been putting off trying this place for awhile now because I never felt like I was much of a waffles kind of gal.  However, I tried it tonight and have to admit its quite good!I had "da throwdown" a la Bobby Flay.  The waffle was perfectly crispy and chewy and the whip cream was light and fluffy.  The best part was the speckaloos! How have I never heard of this before??  It's graham cracker and gingerbread spread... super delicious.  Don't know if I'll have another waffle craving anytime soon but I'm really glad I finally tried it!

I'm torn between two and three stars.  Between, "Meh, I've experienced better..." and, "A-OK".  The waffle itself was outstanding, but I ordered the wafel that won the throwdown and I really didn't like the goop on top.  My fault for ordering the wrong thing.  My initial instinct was to order the one with strawberries and knowing myself I would have enjoyed that much more than the one with the bleeh on top.  I just thought that because it beat Bobby Flay that it would be good.  The lesson is to follow your heart.  You might have a better experience than I did.

My friend and i were downtown walking around and I remembered Wafels and Dinges had a cart down by sea port. It was our first time getting a wafel and since we couldn't decide which wafel we wanted we got  both. Paul was super helpful in helping us wafel virgins understand the types of wafels, explained the toppings and was very entertaining to boot. I'm thinking stopping by everyday to get one since I work right over the Brooklyn bridge... that would burn off some calories right?

Mg i love Wafels and dings lol . after hearing about it from SO many people i finally was able to taste since they were parked a few blocks away from my job . so for breakfast we had the Wafels with powered sugar and strawberries on top and it was too die for . and then us being fat girls we said Wafels for lunch . it was amazing i had the pulled pork on a Wafels and my coworkers had the chili con carne which they loved everything right down to the last bite . i hope to come back to this location  again . it was amazing and they were cool guys to talk to and they were super nice . cant wait to try some of there other items

So this is more of a 3.5 star review, but I tend to err on the side of positive. Particularly with this truck.Fun fact of the day - did you know that August 24th is National Waffle Day?! Well, since I was a smarty and signed up for the W&D email list, I got an email last night saying that the truck is celebrating today. They were offering free toppings ALL day today, along with free wafels from 11:30-12:30.Running late (thanks, post office), I got into the city right at 12:30. The last guy in line (yup, there was a line) said he was the last free wafel recipient. At this point, I figured "Ah hell, I'll just buy one if that's the case." When the W&D santa came over, passing out free posters and magnets, he told me there was no more free wafels. Joking around, I said "Aw, an unemployed girl can't get a break!" and he told me that if I did the job of letting everyone after me know that there were no more free wafels, really work for it, maybe I could get one free!To be honest, I was pleasantly surprised with how friendly everyone working there was. The "Santa's helpers" in the truck were so nice, answering questions ("What the heck is spekuloos?" - Answer? Yummy, peanut butter consistency spread made of biscuits (European, lightly sweetened cracker/cookies.) YUM.)I took a chance with a liege topped with (free!) spekuloos and strawberries and an iced coffee. They fix the coffee to your liking, for anyone that's curious.The liege wasn't probably brand spankin new fresh, but he had popped them back in the press to warm them up. The wafel itself was yummy, chewy, rich. The spekuloos is oddly exactly how the W&D guy described and the tart berries really helped balance everything out. The coffee was good, nothing to write home about.So, here's my summary - for $5, the size of the liege isn't quite... well, for someone with a small wallet, I might feel a little ripped off. But, for a free wafel? Uh-maz-ing. I definitely think it's a great post-bar snack when you're a touch too tipsy to care how much you're paying, hah. Super friendly guys in the truck, great specials on Twitter (follow em), and I'm oddly curious to try this bacon wafel I see reviews for!

Nice.So I decided to walk about 20 blocks to get the liege waffle.  I am not complaining!The waffle was really soft and chewy.  I got it with the spekuloos spread and bananas with powdered sugar on top and it was a great snack.  I also tried  a small bite of the liege waffle with maple syrup and butter and that was actually better than mine.Track it and find it.  The people working the truck are really nice and conversational also.  The waffle had a really great and comforting taste.  I treated it as a dessert - not breakfast!  Btw, when the truck is at 46th street, you can eat at the tables outside down the block. =)
liege waffle still tinkles my fancy. spekuloos is amazing! :)

The waffles are simply perfect. My boyfriend is obsessed with them and whenever he visits me in the city, we go out of our way to find the truck. We usually get the sweet stuff but the savory menu items are great too. Nothing to complain about this wonderful truck.

zomg YUM!  I got "de throwdown" waffle that was supposed to have been on the Throwdown with Bobby Flay.  It's a liege waffle with Spekulos spread and whipped cream.  The waffle was very soft and chewy (different than the fluffy waffles that I'm used to) and it went very well with the speckulos spread.  What is speckulos you ask?  It's mashed Belgian cookies turned into a creamy spread that tastes like a combination of caramel and hazelnut (though I don't think any of those things are actually in the spread lol)Definitely recommend hitting up this truck!PS. It supposedly changes location on a day to day basis, but Friday nights and weekends? (or maybe just Saturday nights, I'm not sure), it's parked on St. Marc's place in the East Village.

I've read about the W&D truck for quite some time, so I was so happy to see them on west 4th on a Friday night.  Even after a filling dinner in the neighborhood, I dragged my boyfriend there because I just HAD to try them.  When I got there, I just stared in wonder and amazement.  The 2 guys there were really friendly and helpful in explaining everything.  I decided to go all out with a liege wafel and WMD (Wafel of Massive Deliciousness).  The WMD is unlimited toppings for an extra $2, so we got strawberries, bananas, nutella, dulce de leche, spekuloos spread (really good!), belgian chocolate fudge and whipped cream. AND on top of that we got a scoop of Tahitian vanilla ice cream.  (Total $9)OMG.  It was disgustingly good!  I really didnt think we would finish all that, but we devoured that on the street like savages.  I can't wait to go get me some yummy W&D again if I can find them!

I had the BBQ Pork over a waffle and all I have to say is, OUTRAGEOUSLY AWESOME!!!  If you are in NYC, you MUST stop by and eat at this truck.  The waffles are so buttery smooth, they melt in your mouth!!!  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!!!

Ok, so I first heard about this food truck on Throwdown with Bobby Flay.  I actually love that show and was very excited to see that the throwdown was "waffles."I decided, win or lose (and they won) that I had to go check this place out.  That waffle looked delicious!  And apparently the spekuloos spread was to die for.I don't even live anywhere near 14th and 3rd, but since I missed my neighborhood day, I made the trek down there all the way from Morningside Heights.Let me tell you this: IT WAS WORTH IT.  The liege waffle is perfectly chewy.  It has just enough bite to it that lends to its awesome texture.  And the spekuloos: no joke.  I don't even really like graham crackers but that stuff is delish. Real good.I will follow that truck wherever it may lead.  Yum.

These things are so addicting. Them belgians have gone and done the unthinkable. They took a decadent wafel, threw fresh fruit on it, drizzled some sweet syrup over the fresh fruit, then powdered the whole thing in sugar. "The fresh fruit balances the other ingredients. The fresh fruit balances the other ingredients," I keep telling myself. How else can I justify eating this overkill-of-a-waffle. I'm sorry, wa-fel (belgian for uber-waffle, apparently). With my conscience thoroughly sedated, I ordered my wafel.My caloric intake of the day was: Light & Crispy Brussels Wafel, topped with fresh strawberries, drizzled with nutella, and sprinkled with powdered sugar. That thing is so heavenly. The wafel was light, crispy, and filling, as advertised. The strawberries were fresh & juicy, not too tart, and not too sweet. The nutella imparts its signature nutty flavor to the mix, but it doesn't oversweeten the wafel as chocolate fudge has a tendency to do. Finally, the powdered sugar just ups the sweetness factor of the whole thing by the slightest bit.The dessert is a work of art. The meal is light but filling, and it's filling without feeling heavy. And, it's sweet, but not overly sweet. I cannot look at a regular waffle without thinking about that Belgian Wafel & Dinges, and I can't walk by their dessert truck with out drooling & reminiscing about my first experience with them.Now, if they could only throw some smothered chicken on there.

Yummy yummy yummy!  I got the little one on the stick, whatever that is called.  It was so warm and soft, omg, I want one whenever I pass the truck, which seems like all the time!  Be wary of confetti sugar on a winter day when you're wearing a black wool peacoat, though.

Whoever created spekuloos was a genius. This is by far one of the best food trucks in NYC. Waffles + Spekuloos + Ice cream makes me forget that nutella even exists! I also enjoy the fact that they are constantly on the move, it makes finding it just a little bit more enjoyable, no?

I think I have a problem:I CANNOT walk by this magical truck without my heart racing and mouth watering.Try as I might to pass it by, I am invariably drawn into the orbit of this magical yellow vehicle.  For only a couple bucks, the good folks are willing to cheerfully hand me a precious, sweet, crunchy, chewy liege wafel loaded with spekuloos.  Bliss!  These wafels bring me JOY.  How many foods legit bring you joy?  Lots of food make me happy, maybe put me in a good mood, and that's great.  But...WAFELS AND DINGES MAKES MY GODDAMNED DAY...EVERY TIME.I've visited various wafel trucks in different locations: Midtown, Astor Pl., Astoria.  I've consistently met by smiling people who LOVE wafels ,and those who gleefully eat them, not to mention the always ridonkulously tasty Belgian goodies.  My workplace recently had an event catered by Wafels & Dinges too, and I'm happy to say, the magic carried over from the happy yellow truck to my bleak and hopeless workplace.   If we got wafels at work more often, I might even start to enjoy my wage slavery.Consistent excellence in product, presentation, and people... they're firing on all cylinders at Wafels & Dinges.I hope Wafels & Dinges sticks around for a LOOONG time.  More importantly, I hope they continue showing up in front of my workplace (39th&Park) on Fridays and my neighborhood (Astoria) on Sundays.DINGES FOREVER!

I remember my first encounter with a real liege waffle like it was yesterday.  I took a weekend detour through Brussels, intent on plundering the vast chocolate, pomme frite and bivalve riches of the city.  Little did I know that the humble street waffle would steal a piece of my heart.  I was laden with baggage, red-faced and rather unpleasantly sweaty from wrestling my luggage upstairs for a train transfer when suddenly...like the seductive wisp of a femme fatale's perfume in a cartoon, the delicious burnt sugar and buttery vanilla aroma of liege waffles floated over and tickled my nostrils flirtatiously.  Like a stallion scenting a mare in heat, I perked up and scanned my surroundings.  I quickly galloped towards the delicious scent, willing, at that point, to fork over any amount to possess the source.  I was divested of EUR 1.10 (~$1.50) and handed a hot, amorphous waffle.  It wasn't much on looks, but one bite and it was suddenly the most beautiful thing I'd ever seen...When Wafels & Dinges first launched, I crowed with delight..."FINALLY!" screamed my deprived tastebuds and teeth, and so I faithfully followed the location feed and found the truck.  The reunion with the liege waffle was bittersweet.  The liege waffle at Wafels & Dinges was delicious but no match to the waffles in Brussels.  There just wasn't enough of that amazing sugar crunch.  On the other end of the spectrum, the waffle at Petite Abielle has too much crunch...the real deal lies somewhere in between, and for my money, despite the tasty Speculoos spread, liege waffles are best eaten plain.  At $5, the Wafels & Dinges waffle is more than triple the price of the street waffles in Brussels.  You could fairly point out the impact of supply and demand, but Petite Abielle's non-truck waffle is just $4I do applaud Chef Thomas and team for a consistently creative approach to classic food.  The menu, which stretches across savory and sweet items, is ever innovative and changing, locations are always easily accessible and the staff is both efficient and friendlyPARTING THOUGHT: And so I continue to be haunted by the matchless perfection of the street waffles in Brussels...

Get the liege waffle (the chewy one) with their signature spekulos spread and banannas or whipped cream. I managed to get the name of the spead out of the guy managing the cart, and it's a belgium spread that they don't sell in the states, but they will start selling it on the cart soon. If you follow the wafel & dinges truck on twitter or facebook, they are always posting clevar and funny tips on how to get free dinges from them. They also post their location schedule as the cart is always switching up their daily location.There is 1 cart stationed daily in the South St. Seaport on Front St.
Yikes, this is an amazing dessert. I think the best part has to be graham cracker flavored ice cream. But definitely one waffle is a huge dessert for just one person.

Just looking at the name "Wafels & Dinges" is making my mouth water. And that's no joke. This is the best desert food truck I've tasted yet. You can eat free here any time of the year and still love it. The only problem is find them. How did they solve this problem? Follow them on Twitter and they'll tell you exactly where their trucks are located. Or you could always do what I do and get lucky. Either way you'll love the outcome.

We waited all week to make it to Waffles & Dinges (hard to get to where they were at the times they were there).  However, this place was well worth the wait.  They have two kinds of waffles - the brussels and the liege.  My favorite was the liege, and we especially liked the spekuloos spread.  Highly recommend getting a WMD (Waffles of Massive Delicousness) because it gives you unlimited toppings (dinges) and that makes for an incredible tasting waffle.  The staff was super nice and friendly and fun, and the music they played was a lot of fun as well.  My favorite truck in New York!

For superb customer service and a business owner who truly cares about his customers needs. =)I'm still not completely on board with the whole price point thing.. but I suppose with inflation I'll get there some day. Thanks guys.
yumm-o, yumm-o, yumm-o!Get the wmd, with strawberry, banana, chocolate sauce and ice cream on top. If your not that hungry get the mini waffle, because its delicious and you look cute eating it.

There's no better way to end an evening partying with my gal than stopping off for some Waffles and Dinges.  Well, maybe there's one better way, but Waffles and Dinges is the perfect precursor.  I get the Liege Waffle with bananas, ice cream, and hot fudge.  Grab some extra napkins or that sucker is going to drip all over your fancy Friday nights duds before you get back to the apartment.  The service at the waffle truck is fast and friendly, the food is delicious, and the lines are there for a reason.  Do yourself a favor and get your dinges on.
Spekuuloos icecream... say no more. I dream every night of this sinful icecream!! Amazing!

I wasn't hungry, but I got a nutella and strawberry one, and it was yummy!  Fresh waffles like my grandma used to make.  My friend got Spekuloos Spread, which is live gingerbread men ground into a spread.  The atrocity, the inhumanity of it all.  But it sure tastes good.  I wasn't even under the influence of any type of drug that would make me hungry.  But I enjoyed it!  Yumtastic.
So damn good! The liege waffle with strawberries, spekuloos and whipped cream is dreamy. I want more.

Yes, this is my third 5-star review, but I just need to reiterate how excellent these wafels are. I had the throw down wafel - speculoos and whipped cream. It was even great after taking it home - their take away boxes are pretty sturdy.

After watching the Wafels & Dinges episode on Throwdown with Bobby Flay, I have been wanting to try their waffles. They looked absolutely delicious through my tv screen. I tried the liege waffle with spekuloos and strawberries. Hubby had liege waffle with nutella and strawberries. First, I have to say, the spekuloos was absolutely delicious! I wish I had bought a jar because I would put that stuff on just about anything sweet.... The liege waffles however, were pretty unimpressed. They were somewhat dry and the texture was chewy and sticky. We had high expectations after reading all of the glowing reviews so we were pretty disappointed. Perhaps we should have ordered the regular belgian waffle instead or maybe they were having an off day but we were definitely underwhelmed with the liege waffles.

Hmm... I have heard a ton about these waffles and even seen them on some "10 Best Desserts" TV show that I found on netflix streaming one night. Tried them a few weeks ago when they came to outside the Queens Center near my place.I got a brussels wafel with belgian choc fudge and whipped cream ($6 I think). The wafel was served in an open-top cardboard carton. The waffle was not bad (fluffy and tasty) but I thought it was really not that special. The Boy (huge waffle fan) shared and agreed that it was good, and probably a little above average, but overhyped. It's a bit messy so I would not be having this with someone you want to impress, or in clothes you paid more than $100 for. Although given it's location, the Wafel is definitley better (and cheaper) than the one I coulda gotten at Georgia Diner down the block....I could eat here again but I wouldn't go out of my way for it. I'm more of a savory-foods type of person too so given the option between Wafel and some other food truck I probably wouldn't waste my calories either.Service was good though - super friendly pair of dudes. I did tell the first "waffle" guy I wanted choc fudge which for some reason I think he didn't hear - but second "toppings" guy was only to happy to help me add on.In summary: Good waffle, safe choice, somewhat overhyped, friendly service.

I think this is the best dessert truck in the world. I came here after eating a full meal and still scarfed down my liege waffle with everyone on it (nutella, spekuloos, whipped cream, strawberry, bananas, and walnuts) like I was a starving child. And it was frickin' cold outside too but this waffle made me feel all warm and happy inside haha. Crispy waffle edges with a moist and chewy center topped with fresh fruits and this amazingly addictive gingerbread spread (which, mixed with nutella = out of this world) made me a believer. This cart was so hyped up for me and it didn't disappoint! Definitely make a trip over here if you are ever in NYC.

I had my first Wafels and Dinges experience last night and it was terrific. I ordered the special Wafle of of DE day which was the Cherry pie ala mode. What is this wonderful creation you may ask? A liege waffle topped with cherry pie filling, belgian chocolate ice cream, crushed spekuloos cookies, whipped cream, and mounds of powdered sugar. Extremely delicious. The waffle was made fresh so it was hot, and chewy but not too heavy and of course with the cold ice cream and all the luscious toppings it was the perfect treat. I cannot wait to come back to try more DIY concoctions I have in my mind.

These waffles are the best I have ever had! If you just need a snack or some dessert this is the best place to go....if you are near one of the trucks. They have so many different toppings. My favorite is the liege waffle with the spekuloos spread (it is basically liquified gingerbread cookies and the most delicious thing you will ever eat) and a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top. Soooo good on a hot summer day. This will be a place I make all my friends and relatives try when they come to visit.

HOT DAMN! This shiz is goooood! I got a deal off of living social to try one savory wafel and one sweet wafel. I was sooo impressed with the BBQ pulled pork wafel - seriously one of the most awesome cart foods I've put in my mouth to date. I also tried a liege wafel for dessert, which was sweet and chewy, and I am now a lover of speckuloos spread. Oh man. It really was a nice treat on a mild summer day  in New York City. I also found the workers to be very attentive and friendly. I am recommending this truck to all of my friends!!

Ran into this truck on a Saturday evening in the west village and I'm glad we stopped! They have an awesome selection, but we just got the waffle with hot fudge and whipped cream. At $6 for a small waffle w/2 dinges, its not the cheapest eat, but its decent between 2 people and a perfect dessert. The waffle was hot, and freshly made, and the fudge was rich and not too sweet. Would love to try the rest of their menu, especially the bacon/syrup! I was happy and if I see this truck again I'm stopping!

Tried this cart on a whim while in New York, having no idea it was so famous, and was just blown away. Delicious! Most amazing waffles ever--my taste buds just exploded with joy.Fav dish: anything with Nutella and their Spekuloos spread

I am glad waffles & dinges is both far from me and expensive - otherwise, I would be big in the waist and small in the wallet. The waffles are light and crispy or chewy. I choose for the light and crispy and weighed it down with half nutella and half spekuloos spread. My only mistake was not getting completely spekuloos. This spread tastes like graham cracker and is surprisingly not too sweet. With the nutella, it was like a vegetarians version of a smore (graham cracker and chocolate only). I could also see this spread being spectacular with strawberries. The staff was helpful and patient on even the coldest of days. I know I will be back often.

Days after my last review, I received a response from the owner with apologies for my poor experience. He offered me a voucher for free waffles to make up for my last visit. It's very impressive when owners take the time to read customer's reviews of their product and take initiative to correct any problems they may have. I just received my voucher the other day and am very eager to pay Wafels & Dinges another visit!

this truck has had a regular stop down in the financial district at hanover square for some time now. i wasn't buying it, because the truck faze has become so over the top, i'm starting to feel like a cultural puppet now when i patronize them. everybody's getting in on the food truck thing, as if that makes the food better. hello, it makes it worse. you have to have the real goods to compensate for waiting around on a city street for your food in the a) cold, b) heat, c) smell, d) wet, e) noise, etc., with no table, no chair, no place. you have to be empty handed too and that is as rare as the trucks are ubiquitous. it's the food equivalent of trying to hear music in a crappy crowded low-ceilinged hot smelly SRO basement club. anyhow, waffles just seemed gratuitous. they're ordinary things, no big deal. truck or no truck, glorifying waffles is like glorifying the asphalt on your street or the color of a pair of jeans or something. right?and yet, after about a year of passing by this truck with a silent good luck, i succumbed when i read some of these yelp reviews and someone mentioned pulled pork waffle. aha. that sounds a little counterintuitive, a little bizarre, and a lot like lunch.so it got me thinking. bread is bread. you start with wheat, you mill it, you bake it, and it's either matzoh or cupcakes. it tastes different but it's basically the same thing. so why not waffle instead of rye bread? pulled pork waffle with bbq sauce, plus a little medium hot sauce, hold the cole slaw, warm up the waffle, and there you go. it was darned good, weird to have the sweetness with the bbq, but then, isn't that what cornbread would normally contribute? the waffle is fluffy, which is another weird thing in this context, but then so is a brioche. so to give credit where credit is due, this is a helluva nice surreal pseudosandwich.as for the whipped cream, nutela, strawberries, whatever, syrups, dessert-type waffles, yelpers love em but you can have em. there's other trucks offering other specialty dessert treats, gourmet finesse mouth-walloping stuff. with this truck, waffle bbq is the way to go. and the truck guys are really nice, which is not a small thing, especially deep in the black belly of the hideously sociopathic wildebeest known as wall street. it is such a pleasure to interact with gentle humans and not have to withstand a ton of attitude, or should i say tonne, given the rootsource...anyway, gotta run -- i'm off to find a ribeye cupcake -- medium rare.

Great! The truck happened to be in my area randomly. I had a nice breakfast before, but decided to grab a waffle and bring it to the car! These bad boys get messy for car eating so beware, but it's because you just fall in love you want to keep eating, lol! They have usually three people int he truck working so it works out nice.. and quick. I had the waffle with the chocolate, bananas, strawberries... yum! I'll find myself back if I see the truck again.

If I could give this truck a million stars I would. It is located on 6th ave between 21/22nd st in front of the new Trader Joes on Tuesdays at 6pm. If you don't absolutely love these wafels you are not human. I had the liege w/ nutella and bananas and I was in pure heavan. The waffle was served warm and I honestly nearly shed a tear with my first bite.

Yum secret recipe from Belgium! (Actually best. wafel. ever. is in Maastricht, the Netherlands). This guy was a little pricey at $5, but a totes yummy, and more importantly, legit liege wafel -- ooey, gooey, warm, and sweet.

Best thing I ate in NYC.  I absolutely LOVE belgian waffles and I make them at home from scratch all the time. When researching places to visit on our recent NYC trip, I knew I had to find one the Wafels & Dinges carts. We went to the one on 72nd/Broadway and was right at the subway exit. Make sure you check the W&D twitter/facebook pages to see where they are and to see what the trivia question/challenge of the day is for a free dinges (topping). I went with the speculoos spread (tasted like a hybrid of peanut butter/nutella/gingerbread cookie spread) and whipped cream. It was the best thing I ate in NYC by far. Definitely check W&D out; you won't be disappointed. oh Wafels & Dinges, I miss you already!!!

MMMM! picked up some from the Kastaar truck near my job in long island city. I loved it! I had the pulled pork, soooo good my coworkers had with sweet dinges. bottom line all 3 of us loved it and the gentleman running the truck were awesome fast, helpful and patient.
I love waffles. Liege waffles are transcendent. Wife dislikes waffles. She loves these. Don't overtop them...just strawberries or bananas.

SOOO GOOD! hands down, best waffles i've had. I would travel just for these waffles. the liege waffle with spekuloos spread and whipped cream... omg this is what I live for! These trucks can be a bit hard to find based on the schedule that they have on their website but they should just open up a permeant store someone in NY, i'll be there 24/7. People are very nice and friendly always welcoming and talking to customers. If you haven't tried these waffles, you are MISSING OUT!

Oh how I wanted so badly to give W&D five stars, but I cannot. After experiencing waffles in Belgium, I have been wanting to find the same food stand experience -- scarfing down a deliciously crispy yet soft waffle. Food truck making waffles in front of you as you order-- check. All the fantastic toppings you can ask for -- check. Very entertaining waffle guy, Joe -- check. So close, but the waffle was not the melt-in-my-mouth experience I have come to expect. I got the WMD with strawberries, chocolate, whipped cream, dolce de leche, and sugar. I suppose I would've given it all 5 stars had I not been to Belgium.

I heart their mini waffels with nutella and banana.  Enough said.  Oh, and their spekuloos spread is pretty good too (it's gingerbread flavored with a consistency that is similar to slightly watered down and melty peanut butter).

Aright, so now I am fully addicted to these ridiculously delicious waffles.  I have their location website page bookmarked on my phone and I find the truck wherever they are.  Sometimes I even brave the tourists and hit up their south street seaport permanent location. The waffles are really unlike any other I've had and they are really always on my mind.  Its getting bad, they know me at the truck now.  They've actually inspired me to make my own waffles and after a few attempts (making authentic belgian waffle dough, not batter) I must say that mine are now the best I've had, bested only by the waffle truck; and now they sell spekuloos so I'm really in trouble.  I'm thinking of getting an apartment near one of their stops so I can get my fix easier.  I really wish they were open late all week!

Mmmm. I stumbled upon this truck in a post-Museum Mile stupor, and lo and behold at 86th and Lexington, was a bright yellow truck that emitted a delicious smell that I couldn't resist. Alas, a waffle with their favorite, spekuloos, and walnuts. Yum. Yum. Yumyum.

Waffles make people happy.  Yellow trucks make people happy.  Belgian chocolate makes everything 100% times better.  I arranged to have the truck come out to set for my crew last night.  It was the end of a hard week and just the sight of the truck buoyed spirits.  Then once the breeze turned and brought the smell of fresh baked waffles over - forget it.  I personally had waffles, ice cream, belgian hot chocolate and no I couldn't ask for whipped cream it was too much.  The waffles were hot and crispy melting the vanilla bean specked ice cream and that chocolate.  One girl came back and just asked for a shot of the chocolate.My crew was happy, we ended the week on a happy note.  Couldn't ask for anything more.

I was in New York last Thursday wandering about for hours.  I really do not know the area well at all.   I just  dig the bustle and sights.I had seen the Bobby Flay Waffle Throw-down and almost as a joke said to my guy..  Hey if you see the the Waffles and Dinges truck, i'm so going to try one.   Well about three hours and 60 blocks of walking later.. tired and full from other adventures along the way the truck was spied.   OMG... but i'm tired... but i'm full...  and I was told, if you walk away right now, you will be so disappointed and dammit he was right (he usually is LOL)..So I ordered the Throw-down Waffle.  Everyone..  it was just lovely.  I was with two others and we shared, as we walked taking big bites wearing whipped cream and big smiles.Well worth the stop!
The delicious smell pull me to this truck in the St. Marks area, the speculoos ice cream (tastes like teddy grahams!) was really tasty!  I only got one scoop of ice cream and it was HUGE!

Always stop at the Columbus Circle truck  for a wafel  (Liege are the best!) topped with spekuloos.  So good!  Wait staff are always helpful.  Don't be fooled by the "cookie butter" that Trader Joes sells-it doesn't come close to this spekuloos spread.We buy extra and bring them home-they save well for a couple of days-yum!

Delicious, get their specialty waffle (with Speculuos), nice, chewy and full of flavor. Best waffles I've eaten. We went on Christmas when they where on Bryant Park. Amazing, they get all their fruits fresh from the farmers markets, and it tastes that way! I truly recommend getting a hang of them while in New York. They are a food truck so you should check them on Twitter to locate them! ;)

I liked the lightness of the liege waffle!  I'm not a big fan of the spekuloos spread tho.  My friend order one with chocolate and I was jealous...AHAHHAI had one bite of hers and...it was delicious!The guys on the truck were really friendly, this is probably one of their selling points as well too.  Great job!!!And if i'm not mistaken....they kicked bobby's butt in the Throw Down!! props to you guys!
The best waffles with the greatest service. I don't remember what that thing I ate with it so I will call it spanakopita or spephanopolous... but it was great!!!

Great for on the street dessert.The Spekuloos spread is something that has to be tired.  It is like a graham cracker in spreadable form.While in season, the ice cream sandwich (between two waffles that is) is the best.  They will put a warm sauce or spread of your choice on one side; then flip the whole sandwich when they hand it to you.  This way when the warm sauce hits the cold ice cream you have nothing but wonderful bliss. Take extra napkins and enjoy!

One word.....AMAZING.  Every time I am in NYC I seek this truck out.  If I could make a suggestion for heaven it would be the Liege waffle with bananas, strawberries, whipped cream, chocolate sauce, and powdered sugar, the taste is simply amazing.  The employees are always nice and inviting and service is quick and efficient.  If you are in NYC and want a sweet treat, find yourself Dinges!!!

I bumped into this truck by chance. Thank goodness not literally but that's besides the point. I was on my way to the train station with my friends after a night of sushi, pomme frites and ice cream. I was already full but was curious to see what this yellow truck was offering from a distance. WAFFLES!!  Snowboarding season has been over since March but this is the spot to get the same great waffles (Liege Waffles) from the Waffle Cabins at the bottom of those mountains. (i.e. Killington, Stratton) So this made me happy and savored these delectable waffles! Plus the guys were really nice =)

I can say with no hesitation, that these are the best waffles I have ever had.  They are butter hot and just the right size.  I had the bacon waffle with syrup, I didn't even need extra dinges, but next time I will get dinges just to see if the perfect waffle can get more perfecter...lol

If my stomach were about to explode, because I had eaten 4 cows, and then I saw Wafels & Dinges - I would still go. In fact, I have been in a similar situation before. Who cares about having whip cream and syrup running down your face when that wafel you have with luscious cream whipped to perfection on top of deep red strawberries begging to be eaten all covered in (what I believe to be laced with crack) nutella and syrup is still right in front of you. If I could marry a Wafels & Dinges truck, I would.

I have had only one wafel with speculoos sauce and I am craving another.  I wish it were coming back this weekend, I am considering trekking to the truck tomorrow.  I will be bringing mix & sauce back home.
A little overpriced and overrated but solid overall.  Would re-visit when in the city although I wouldn't make it a point to go

Fabulous, fabulous waffles. I've tried it with Nutella and Speculoos which were both great - they have a stand right near as well as in Central Park and it's a great thing to split between friends after a day in the park.

Since I had never been here before, I decided to get the works, a Liege Wafel with spekuloos, nutella, whipped cream, strawberries, and bananas. OMG SO GOOD. The waffle itself was dense and chewy and buttery and amazing and probably the best waffle I've ever had. The spekuloos, which I had never tried before, tasted like a gingerbread in spread form, which was absolutely fantastic.Next time I think I'll just get spekuloos and bananas because, while getting so many toppings was too delicious for me to be overwhelmed, it was probably way too many calories. Haha. And the spekuloos by itself was more than good enough as a topping by itself.

freddy makes it the best!  the curly-haired cutie recommended the "throwdown" waffle, winner of the throwdown with bobby flay!  it had this delicious peanut-butter-lookalike spread called "spekuloos" (tasted a bit like pb, too!), whipped cream, and nutella (i requested the chocolate as extra). it was so yummy in my tummy. it was a gooey, warm, melt-in-your mouth sweet taste of heaven. a bit hard to cut. you definitely need a knife and a good pair of chompers!my sister and i liked it so much that she went and got it the next week, and she said it didn't taste as good for some reason...? i'm convinced freddy was the magic ingredient...and spekuloos! where are you, freddy?? ;) come find me!

But I would walk 500 milesAnd I would walk 500 moreJust to be the man who walked 1000 milesTo fall down at your doorSo this place has been on my list of to do's in NYC for a while.Friday as I was riding the bus up from DC I got the twitter: "Sorry kids were are in NJ serving making hundres of kids at camp happy with our waffles".   OH! NO! I prayed they would be back in NYC the next day, as I was leaving Sunday.Saturday Morning Twitter " We are in Brooklyn @ 7th Ave and Carroll. Sing a MJ song and get a second topping free!"  Okay....time to explore whatever is in that area just so I can eat a waffle.  So I dragged my cousin and her friend from Queens to Park Slope for the waffles.We get to the truck, finally!  I ordered the Liege waffle--the guy asked what topping I wanted, and I said none.  He looked at me curiously.  I guess I was anti-topping because when I lived in Holland the waffles were sans topping often, and that is how I liked them.  Anyway, I gave in and had butter. num num num.  Delicious.So I went back to the cart (because I figure all the walking made the first waffle calorie neutral), this time Eddie was at the helm.  He asked what I was up to and I had to admit that I had spent most of my day getting to him---and it was totally worth it.  Took me back to my study abroad days. So I asked Eddie what speculoos was, one of the toppings options---and he gave me a sample.  You know those Biscoff cookies you get on the plane sometimes?  We this is a sauce that tastes just like that  (maybe because it comes from a jar called Biscoff sauce, haha).  It tasted delicious---.Anyway, follow them on twitter, and when you find them enjoy.

I've tried to recreate what Wafles and Dinges does with their spekuloos spread, thinking the Trader Joe's cookie spread might work, but it's just not the same. Gotta catch the waffle truck! Sticky, messy, sweet, and oh, so satisfying. This was the first Liege wafel I'd had since actually visiting Liege, where I ate so many I could barely fit out my hotel door upon leaving. Just kidding but they are addictive! I like my Liege wafel with the spekuloos spread, whipped cream and strawberries. So tasty! I'm craving one right now!
Overrated. Way too sweet. The wafel wasn't even soft, just really stiff and sticky. The other four friends who ate it also had the same sentiments.

Waffles and Dinges parks every Friday morning right next to my office, and yes, I allow myself the wonderful sin.I always order the soft waffle with Spekulos, yummy!!For the ones who are not familiar, here's how you order this yummy goodness: first, choose your waffle, then your toppings (the so-called dinges). That's it, so simple! Well, I make it a little more interesting and choose a cool name when they write it down. After all, it's Friday.Enjoy!The only pet peeve I have is to try and eat a waffle on the street with a knife and fork, not the easiest thing. I end up carrying it to the office and eating at my desk.One little tip is to call the number listed on their website and hear what you need to do for a free topping. I remember during Halloween you had to "scare" the truck guys. A little silly thing that saves you some money, after all the waffle with one free topping is already $5.Love it, makes my Fridays all the better.

Amazing food truck in the city. Had these waffles in Cental Park topped with warm nutella, whip cream, strawberries, and a delicious brown sugar sauce (spekuloos sauce) that left me craving for more. The waffles come out hot and freshly coaked- perfectly textured and prepared in front of you the sauces don't make the waffle itself moist. The ice creams are also delicious- brown sugar spekuloos ice cream is packed with flavor. This food truck is a must try!

I broke all kinds of no carbs, sugar intake and other nonsensical rules when I stopped by the truck on Midtown West for lunch. As a first timer, I was pleased with the cool dude who served me up my dinge - straberries, whipped cream and spegulous. Delish!

My waffle was pre-made and it was not good at all.  It was hard and cold.  I'm sure a freshly made waffle is really good but for $3 or 4 a waffle, they should not be selling pre-made waffles.  They're terrible.  Needless to say, I'm not going to bother trying it again.  They should consider if it's worth it to cut corners in exchange for a bad review.

Like bees waiting to mate or make honey or whatever it is they do when researchers aren't injecting them with cocaine, the Wafels and Dinges truck and I have been engaged in a delicate dance of courtship and seduction for several months now. Usually when I happen upon it, I'm on my way home from consuming 400% of my daily recommended caloric intake in popcorn (when it's parked at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas) or mojitos (when it's by Union Square).Tonight, the mood was finally right.And it was as gentle, sweet, and perfect as it could possibly be.I don't know what the below reviews are talking about -- this tasted exactly like the Liege waffles did in Brussels, maybe because I got mine at Christopher Street and ate it in the subway, just like I did in Brussels. It's all about context. The guys sitting next to me on the train were jealous!Also, the wafelman was super-nice and gave me a lot of free toppings (dinges?). Definitely a value at $4!

Unfortunately, the subsequent waffles I've had at the Columbus Circle and Central Park trucks have not been good--the waffles were under-heated or undercooked, so the middle was soggy and almost tasted raw. I was disappointed since on both occasions I was introducing the wafel to my family and friends. My advice? Perhaps find the bigger truck, or just hope you're lucky.

Cause of death - SUGAR OVERLOAD!!!I had the soft and chewy "Liege" waffle ($5) with unlimited toppings ($2).Toppings:1) banana2) strawberries3) spekuloos (I still have no idea what this is made of, but it's darn good!)4) chocolate fudge5) nutellaYyp, you read that correctly... THREE fricken flavors of sauce added to it. What the heck was I thinking?!?!?!?!?! Lesson learned, next time I should go with only ONE sauce, or ask them to separate it. Overall, the waffle was delicious. Nice, soft, chewy. Yummy yummy in my big ol' tummy!!

I love WAFELS & DINGES! The throwdown wafel is the bomb, but my favorite thing is to go for a run in Central Park and then "cooldown" and replenish my glycogen with a  wafel with strawberries and whip cream from the Columbus Circle cart.  Just looking forward to that wafel makes my run easier.

I was excited to try this place. Saw the line, so must be fantastic. It turned out to be alright and just over priced. I had much better waffles for less money. Spent a total of $9.25 for the baconanna waffle and it was tiny. Barely a snack for me and my GF. If you came to New York to visit, it is worth a try but don't get your hopes up too high.

This is the scoop. One white guy and one Hispanic guy operate the truck. The Hispanic guy was clearly not the boss, cuz when I asked when the 2nd truck is coming, he said his boss was looking into it. No, not because he's Hispanic you racist bastards. I digress. There's a pdf menu of their offerings on their website along with special dinges displayed on a whiteboard when you get there. Today's special dinges happened to be honey, coconut flakes and bananas. They also offered Iced Coffee (Reg, Hazelnut, Vanilla, Chocolate). Regarding the freshness of the wafels, there were some already on the counter but ours were made to order. Maybe you have to specifically request yours fresh. When asked, they said the ones on the counter were there 'resting and cooling down'. Wow, even their NYS License Plate reads WAFEL. Tax is included.Wafels $4 (+$1 per topping or +$3/unlimited toppings):-Brussels - this square waffle would be the one you could relate to most, light, airy, fluffy, and crispy, the one they serve at brunch places, i liked this better of the two actually, will get next time, i tried this-Liege/Liege Cinnamon Royal - not sure if I tasted the sugar pearls here but this was more doughy and heavier on the tummy, it was fresh and tasty though, being the badass that I am I ordered 'the works' minus maple syrup, honey, and dulce de leche.Note: A sport bottle of Poland Spring (24oz) will run you $2. Some yahoo waited on line just for this.Thanks to nycfoodguy.com for informing me about this and enticing me with oh so orgasmic pics:nycfoodguy.com/2008/09/0…P.S. Check Twitter for their daily locations. 1 truck moves between several locations at any given daytwitter.com/waffletruckTotal came out to $7 after everythingPics: meetup.com/teamfoodie/ph…

Got the regular wafel with bbq pulled pork and coleslaw on top. Coming out of the bar at 1:30, how could I resist waffles and bbq pork? The waffle didn't disappoint, made fresh, light, crispy and quite tasty on its own. The pulled pork was serviceable. I've had better pulled pork, but I really love my slow cooked swine so I tend to order it often, and a rating of "not bad" on my scale is pretty damn good, especially for a waffle truck. The BBQ sauce could have been KC masterpiece for all I know, it was pretty generic and very sweet. Coleslaw was quite tasty. The weird maraschino pickles were good on the first bite, and an unwelcome surprise on the following, I would probably skip those next time. Fold it up and eat it like an unholy waffle sandwich. Yum.
So delicious!!  All fresh ingredients, and the nicest staff!I cannot tell you how much I look forward to Thursdays when the Wafels & Dinges truck is in my neighborhood!

The bacon waffle with strawberries and whipped cream is soooo good! The guy in the truck let me try some spekuloos since I never had it before...I'll be getting it on my waffle the next time I run into the waffle truck.

So I was in NYC for work for all of 36 hours and happened upon a food stand city in Chelsea made up of a bunch of food trucks and I had to stop and check it out.  A friend of a friend mentioned that if I saw this place I HAD to get one.  So heading her advise I got in line and ended up with the best waffle of my life.  I'm not sure what Spekuloos is but I wish I had bough some to take home with me to CA.  It's AMAZING.  Forget Nutella... that was sooo last year.  Spekuloos is the real deal.  I got it with bananas.  I'm salivating just thinking about it.  Go try it!!!!

Liege wafel + spekuloos spread. Simple but absolutely delicious. Expensive...but you will probably forget what you paid as soon as you start eating.My friend excitedly introduced this to me as we were walking toward the union sq subway stop. He insisted that I try a leige wafel with this magical spread that he described as "cookie in a peanut butter jar" type spread. okay...not the biggest fan of peanut butter, but he seemed really excited about it. So why not?He simply just went ahead and ordered for us -- I didn't even have time to fully comprehend the menu! But he seemed pretty confident, and because I had never tried the Liege wafel, he said I had to try some. And yes -- every first timer should try it! The Liege wafel was definitely the best waffle I've had in my few decades of living -- doughy, moist, and toasty. Combined with the magical spekuloos spread on top with a bit of powdered sugar -- which was being slowly melted nicely by the hot waffle -- was absolutely delicious.I don't know what that spread is but...freakishly delicious spread. It's probably best I don't purchase a jar in the fear that I'll become malnutritioned from eating nothing but that thing.And oh, just to mention that this eating experience was AFTER eating two dinners. Yes, not one...but two. I'm not a dessert person to begin with, and being pretty darn full...I wasn't sure I'd eat much of it. But we finished the whole thing without hesitation.  WHILE grocery shopping at trader joe's right across from the truck. Perfect combination and ending to a foodie's night. YUM.

So good! I love that they're open super late. My boyfriend and I were bored in NJ around midnight and decided to get some delicious food, and all it took was looking up where the truck was (easy to find on their website) and driving over there! The spekuloos spread is really good. I recommend the liege waffle over the Brussels one, though both are quite good. Banana and Nutella are good additions, too!

I was like a kid in a candy shop when I saw this at the Union Square Holiday Markets... nearly peed in my pants! I got the WMD liege waffel with everything but the kitchen sink. The spekuloos spread is a drug people!

I went out with a friend last night who seems to be going through a breakup that, were it to have a rival in the history of man, would have to be some piece of Greek mythology. She spends a portion of each day sobbing in an awkward fashion, after which we come up with a game plan to cheer her up. I'm totally down for the "after which" part, because it tends to involve roaming around while eating and drinking.Last night, after a particularly quiet round of sniffling, we went to a few places, most of which I have already reviewed. The place we ended up at, however, I have not.I have passed by this truck almost countless times.This time, we had to stop. In fact, we stopped twice. The first time we stopped, she loudly complained that she 'didn't want any dessert shit because she wasn't done eating, yo'. This took us to Crif Dogs to finish stuffing our faces with bacon-wrapped and artery clogging amazing-ness. When we were done with that, she had apparently decided it was now time to face the dessert.. Yo.We stood in front of the cart.And stared at the menu.And had no idea what to order.Fortunately, I had heard of this cart, as well as seeing it, and knew of its fame in defeating Bobby Flay (who seems to lose many throwdowns to things in NY, just saying) and so we determined that the thing to order would be the Throwdown Wafel. Turns out, this was indeed the thing to order. I can't speak of the other things that are on this cart. I can't speak for other items, places, people or pets or whatever else there is out there. Most of these things are because I am writing this review at 5pm while drunk. But also because this thing was effing heaven on a little piece of thin and folded cardboard.Waffle+Spekuloos+Whipped Cream+Powedered Sugar+two guys in a cart that are hysterically funny= amazing food truck experience.Nothing less than 5 stars, and that's rolling in the fact that my coat got enough powdered sugar on it to look like i'd stepped in on a party with Motley Crue. Minus the porn tape, of course.

One cold, miserable night I left work to make my weekly Trader Joe's run. Much to my disgust, there was a LINE to get into TJ's, and I had to wait. So I stood there feeling sad and weepy... until I saw this Wafels & Dinges truck sitting right in front. My lifesaver!So I went over to scan the menu and settled on the cinnamon liege wafel with nutella. The first thing that bothered me was that my wafel wasn't made fresh; it was actually barely warm when I got it. The cinnamon taste was strong and satisfying and went really well with the nutella, though, so that redeemed it. For $5, it was a good treat and relief from the TJ's line. I think I'd only come back and get another wafel here if I knew that mine would be fresh, or in the very least, more than just lukewarm. Maybe I'll try again soon.
This sweets truck is a real treat if you ever find it around your local neighborhood. The Dulce de Leche Wafel is like swimming in a waterfall of caramel goodness. I love  Wafels & Dinges!
So good.  Liege wafel, WMD Dinges... Speculoos Spread, Belgian Chocolate fudge, bananas, strawberries, whipped cream, powdered sugar.  Yes.

My friend and I came across this dessert truck quite serendipitously on our way to our bi-weekly joy trip to Trader Joe's.  It was parked right outside and a crowd of teenagers bearing whipped cream laden paper trays of aromatic happiness was the first clue that we wouldn't just be getting groceries today.  After getting our groceries, we decided that someone would get a Brussels and the other would get the Leige.  The Brussels was fresh made, but the Leige was pre-made and then reheated (BOO.  BOO BOO BOO.)  The guy was pretty friendly and when he forgot to give my friend a fork and knife, he added another topping for free. The waffles themselves were OOOkay.  The Leige tasted like compressed danish that had been caramelized on the outside.  It IS much denser, chewier, and richer, but I think the fact that it was merely reheated kind of took the fun out of it for me. The Belgian wouldn't have tasted good without the toppings--dark, really rich belgian chocolate fudge sauce and the whipped cream didn't taste like it was watered down either.  At $5 each ($4 for the plain Leige waffle), while I'm glad I tried it, I think I would have rather spent the money (and calories!) at Dessert Truck.

I saw an email via DailyCandy ages ago and had been dreaming of waffles on wheels.  I checked out their site and even considered getting a group of people together so that we could get them to come to us instead of us having to track them down.Finally checked it out in front of Trader Joe's and got 2 waffles (brussels and  liege):If you must, get the:Brussels (crunchy, light and yum yum): I agree w/ the description but might have to take away one "yum".  It was crunchy but a little too light and airy.  We ordered it w/ strawberries sand whipped cream.Skip the: Liege (chewy, rich and flavorful): chewy yes...rich and flavorful...I'll have to think about it.  It was significantly smaller than the brussels wafel and way too chewy.  It was a struggle to even come close to finishing b/c it just wasn't that good.  Got this w/ strawberries and powdered sugar (in an attempt to minimize caloric intake) and have come to the conclusion that whipped cream or ice cream (wish it was available) is a MUST.Iced Coffee: not bad, but not that great.  Could've used more ice and cream.If I want waffels, I'm going to hit up Petite Abeille - they have one w/ vanilla ice cream, whipped cream, and chocolate sauce that makes for an awesome dessert to share at brunch!
So good. We have gotten it all. When we have out of town guests, this is a food truck must.

Not gonna lie, this was pretty damn good. Got the spekloos spread and whipped cream on a waffle and it was mindblowing. About $6 for a waffle, which isnt cheap but its definitely worthwhile every now and then. Will def be coming back

Ran across the food truck in central park. (by 5th Ave and 60th St).  Even though the line didn't look too long, it goes pretty slow so expect to wait for a bit.  Tried the Throwndown Wafel which had whip cream and drizzeled with spekuloos.  The wafel was warm chewy and w/ the toppings it was out of this world.

The bacon-syrup wafel is good, but not quite as bacon-y as I expected. But it could not compare with the liege (soft & chewy wafel) with spekuloos (their special spread), nutella, strawberries, banana and vanilla ice cream. The beer ice cream is really unique and yummy, but we still thought vanilla sounded better with everything else on the wafel. The guys working at Wafels & Dinges are so friendly that waiting in the rain was not at all unpleasant.

Thank you for providing sobering sustinence during my time of need. After drinking my weight in beer at Vahalla, I was looking forward to eating at Pomme Frites. But three feet from the door, the boy, in all of his drunken splendor, chose to violently eject the contents of his stomach.After buying him water, I decided the best option would be for us to split apart and find a taxi on different corners. Well somehow, his booze-n-puke adled mind missed the memo on picking me up in said taxi....because I couldn't find him anywhere within the Astor Place vincinity.Then I laid my alcoholic eyeballs on your sweet, sweet truck. After hearing my saga of the puke-n-dashed boy, your owner oh so kindly gave me his cell phone to use...until I realized that A- because my phone was stolen a week ago, I didn't have my boy's number on hand (or memorized) and B- my night had officially reached Murphy's Law status.But you provided me with a free crispy, yet soft cinnamon wafel topped with whipped cream, nutella, and scrawberries for my solo cab ride home the Bronx...so my night wasn't all that bad.Thank you, Wafel and Dinges for restoring my dignity. Thank you.
Delicious waffles, especially the pulled pork.

Cold winter day...hot & soft, freshly made liege waffle covered with gooey speculoos (gingerbread cookie) spread and powered sugar. Oooo, simply ubertastic! Got one at the W&D stall at Union Sq. this past weekend. $5 of deliciously crafted heaven. The sauce is not nauseatingly sweet but thick and creamy like natural peanut butter. The wait was like 7 minutes and there were about 6 people in front of us and this was on a weekend in Union Sq.

I always wanted to find the truck after hearing so much about it on tv. I was not disappointed. I have to say those where some of the best waffles I have ever had. I tried the Liege Wafel with strawberries, bananas, spekuloos spread, and whipped cream. Delicious. The people there were also great and service was fast. I have to try their other options the next time I see them. If it comes to it I'll just track them down online.
Incredible Belgian Wafels.  Can  not have enough of.  Don't forget to get extra cup of Belgian Hot Chocolate.
The waffles here are AMAZING! It's crispy (not soggy!) and loaded with sugary goodness! If I ever run into this truck then I'm ordering everything on the menu.. no joke.

YUM! love raspberry vanilla ice cream, strawberries and bananas with nutella drizzle over a waffle! filling for $7! the honey beer ice cream was good too...i liked it a bit better but didn't have much of a beer taste.

I was looking for some turtles one sunny day when I happened upon a yellow cart that I thought might be selling some Ralph Lauren Rugby clothing. After said turtles were found and lovingly gazed on for seconds on end, I realized that the cart was the infamous Wafels and Dinges. Backtrack: Prior to walking into Central Park, "Germy" had retraced his steps to an ice cream vendor in search of dessert, but was not pleased with the options. Flashforward: bemused, I said to Germy, well if you want something sweet, this is as good a place as any aaannnnddd it's not everyday that you run into it. Not in the know about the whole dealio, I had to explain it to him. Intrigued, but not willing to be overwhelmed, he ordered a brussels wafel with melted chocolate fudge and a scoop of ice cream. While we were waiting, the guys inside were incredibly friendly and such a delight to talk to. Unfortunately for us, the chocolate hardened so quickly that it turned into a "magic shell" of sorts making it nearly impossible to eat with plastic utensils on a park bench. It might have soured the experience for the both of us. I'm not going to tell you that it didn't taste good, but it didn't reach stellar heights either. However, if I ever find myself in the neighborhood and in the mood for something sweet, I may consider trying something else for novelty's sake. For $5, you really can't go wrong.Location: North of the Great Lawn, South of Turtle Pond, Central Park

This is my FAVORITE food truck!  Their liege waffle is AMAZING, and for only 7 dollars you can get it w/ ALL the fixings - nutella, their famous spekuloos spread (it tastes like gingerbread), walnuts, whipped cream, belgian fudge, etc (ice cream is an extra $2).  The best way to get your sugar/dessert fix, and I wish I could have this everyday for breakfast.  The vendors are also really friendly...one of them told us "don't count your calories, make your calories count!"  It was really cold outside when my friends and I followed this truck to 62nd & Broadway, but we ended up sitting in a bank of america atm to enjoy our warm, freshly made waffles.

Used to go here all the time a year or two ago almost all the time. To the point where one of the guys used to recognize me which hinted at a wafel problem that I was developing. Brought about 10 of my friends to the truck and they've converted to wafel fiends and helped spread the word of the truck. The brussels wafel with speckalos spread, whipped cream, chocolate sauce, and strawberries will forever be the bomb.

Waffles with spekuloos is realllly yumm!  But c'mon, $7 for a waffle with some topping...?  For $3 more, I can walk into a restaurant in St. Marks and get real food.  For $3, I can actually sit and eat and not sweat while I'm eating the waffle.  A definitely must try at least once, cause that spekuloos is something... something really good.
The texture (yeast?) and the glaze remind me a lot of a cinnamon bun. Anyone else get that?I told the guy his cart was a beacon in a sea of shit for breakfast.

i spotted them on 46th street between 5th and 6th ave - i dunno if this is a "branch" truck, but IM GLAD THEY WERE THERE WHEN I WAS!it was a day of food rhymes, so i had my moishe's falafel for lunch and a mini wafflini for dessert, because you know, falafels rhyme with waffles.not knowing what a spekuloos spread was, i asked about it and they told me that it was like a peanut butter that tastes like graham cracker. uh, ITS A SPREAD THAT'S ON CRACK. hello?im also glad that they have the mini wafflini because really, i know that im a big sweets girl, but there's only so much room i can save for dessert - and kudos to you guys for having it!thanks for letting me walk into someone's office with powdered sugar all over me, but hey - i would do it all over again.

I freakin LOVE these waffles.  There is nothing like a fresh hot belgium waffle with Nutella and sliced ripe bananas.  The waffle was soft, hot and chewy and the Nutella was warm, so it was drizzled all over my waffle.  It was sooooooooo good.

Waffles--er, wafels--don't excite me, but if they did, this might get four stars. I got the mini-wafelini, which comes with a strawberry (cute!). It seems to be tiny, but I wound up at Whole Foods later, and holy bojangles. Something of that size is about 250 calories. It was pretty good; warm, slightly chewy. I asked the man to add dulce de leche after I'd had a bite of my wafel, and he cheerily obliged. I'm not sure if he charged me, but I put $1 in tip cup, so either way, he was very nice about it.

So good! Be warned these waffles are soooo filling, though. And the waffles themselves are sweet, so you might not want to get ice cream on top. Some nutella, strawberries, and whipped cream is just right. You will feel like you've died and gone to heaven! Their hot cocoa is wonderful too. It's a little different... cinnamon? Maybe some nutmeg? Really good.

Okay, wait a second...they sell Belgian Waffles...out of a truck...anybody who doesn't rate this a five star find is out of their mother loving mind.I had heard a rumor about a magical yellow truck that brought hope to New Yorkers by emancipating them from the shackles of ultra chic dessert places (if I see one more crepe place in this city I am going to hang myself)...and low and behold one glorious day, that beautiful truck in all it's immaculate yellowness appeared and spit out a plate of Cinnamon Waffles with Strawberries, whipped cream, and....wait for it....NUTELLA!!!  AND IT WAS FREE!!!  Okay, it wasn't free, but 6 bucks feels like free when you're wolfing down a Cinnamon freaking waffle...did I mention the generous slathering of Nutella?!?Seriously, these things are ridiculous (in a good way).  I am currently considering heisting this truck and riding it back to the celestial kingdom where it came from...where the streets are made of Waffles and the rivers are pure Nutella...
A liege wafel with strawberries and spekuloos. Honestly, I can't think of anything more perfectly delicious. Every day that I'm not eating one, I wish I was.

It was love at first bite. My boyfriend and I shared a brussels wafel with unlimited dinges (spekuloos spread, whipped cream, strawberries, bananas, and belgian chocolate fudge). If I could eat without getting fat, I would eat this everyday.

Oh my god!! Best thing I've had in a long time! I had my waffle in Herald Square with dulce de leche and whipped cream. Delicious! It had probably a little too much whipped cream but however I loved it! The service was excellent, though it would've been nice if the tables had chairs to enjoy them better. This is definitely a must have.

i got the throwdown. in case you were wondering, spekuloos is cookie butter like the stuff you get at trader joes; really thick and peanut buttery. the waffle itself is amazing and i lovelovelove whipped cream. you get a dollar off with a yelp check-in coupon and the vendors are super friendly and awesome. :]

My entire NYC trip, I was searching for this truck like it was a bury treasure! Finally found it and it was all worth it. Bought four boxes of Brussels and two boxes of liegewafel w/ nutella. Brussel waffles were ok but the ligewafel was delicious!

I was visiting New York 2 weeks ago for the first time and knew I had to eat off this truck after seeing it on Throwdown w/ Bobby Flay.  Anyway, Liege waffel w/ nutella was yummy and I scarfed it down.  A lot of kids walked by me drooling, and begging their parents to get them a waffle.  Sorry kids, all for me! ha.  I would def. go back next time I'm in New York city.  There are also a couple of wafels & Dinges carts hanging around Manhattan as well but I saw them the same day I ate off the truck so I didn't compare the truck vs. cart yumminess.  Reading the other yelp reviews it sounds like they have different ice cream flavors. doh! wish I had realized that 2 weeks ago.

Shame on me for only recently trying Wafel & Dinges.The 1st time I tried this, I went back 4 more times the same week. Can you say ADDICTED? Get the WMD, it's totally worth it. For $7 you can get all the toppings your little heart desires (Spekuloos is a MUST!) and for an extra dollar you can add ice cream. The iced coffee is also great and the employees are always so friendly. In my opinion, this is hands down the best dessert in the city.

I love Waffles, so why? Why did you have to break my heart Mr. Degeest? You want to know the story of my sorrow? A picture is worth a thousand words....                                           ,onaSaturday,          ,eveningme,                                       anD"yelperscaM,   ,etothewestVilla                                     gE'andstarving, "SaW" theWafels&di                                    NGesyellowtruck.Wethoughtourselves                                                                     savedfromthepangsofhunger;themeret                                                                                                                                                                                         *cRracKk*                                    houghtofdelightingindeliciouslysweet-                                                 Wafflessplatteredw-whippedcream-                                                                                                                                              showeredbystrawberrysyrup,pow                                                                             deredwithsugarand vanilla,all                                                cametoasuddendeath,the'                                                    momentwetastedtheb                                                        landcrust-and-tas                                                             telessexcuse                                                                 forawaffle                                                                      o_OSo yes, this is a Valentine's review, but this time, love stinks.

Big Belgium waffle fan and in all my years of waffle consumption I have never had anything comparable to this! A great way to start a morning or for a quick snack. If your in New York, you have to check these guys out.

riding through the park on my bike all day- cause the filfth took away my license....(sorry, i was attempting to channel Lily Allen- but this is NYC, not London) on a rainy Friday afternoon, i was strolling around Park Avenue on my way to work when suddenly.. the clouds cleared up for a moment and the sun's glimmer sparkled and twinkled in my eyes. there i see it. waffles. waffle samples. waffles with whipped cream. for a second, i had a double-take. when you walk by something and you have to go back to see it again out of curiosity... because something is different. i thought i was passing a MUD (coffee) truck, but no... not today, folks. it was a Belgian Waffle Truck. parked right in front of a Vegetarian eatery and my favorite Deli- i thought i was hallucinating. i don't even LIKE Belgian Waffles. however, the freshly-pressed scent of the soft/chewy waffles accompanied by Nutella (which i don't like usually, either). something immediately put me in a trance... "buy one.... buy one...." i didn't even ask for a sample, i just lined up-ordered-salivated while they were putting it together- and then gobbled up the waffle at work. yup... didn't even start on my lunch, i went straight for the goods. i don't know what has come over me. Thomas Degeest is the Chief Wafel Master. he's also cute and undoubtedly charming/sweet. i asked a lot of dumb questions... like WTF is a dinges? (ding-ee) he told me it meant, "toppings". ahh. eureka. Waffles & Toppings. i would have to give it a thumbs up for cuteness (the waffle master) and the deliciously prepared Vanilla Waffle with Nutella, Strawberries, and Fresh Whipped Cream. *droool*

This waffle truck is awesome! I had the liege with nutella and strawberries and my bf had the Throwdown (waffle with spekuloos and whipped cream). Both were delicious, but the Throwdown was much better! Spekuloos (gingerbread spread) is so yummy!

Nutella on anything makes me happy. I cry a little bit every time I devour one of these things because a) hello gym, b) I know how quickly it's going to disappear, and c) I don't have enough time to go back in line and get another one.So I usually get two. And I call myself a little bit of a fatty.-----{(Nutella + strawberries + whipped cream)/(waffle)}/(insert in mouth)=(awesome)

Tried their special they had on Bastille Day on 60th, which had Blue Berries, Strawberries and Whip Cream. Waited in line for about 15-20 minutes, but worth it. Staff working the event were very friendly and didn't mind being video taped.

Ok I traveled all the way from Vegas to enjoy this delightful truck. I started with a more traditional wafel with strawberry and maple syrup. I couldn't resist getting more then one wafel, so I tried the throw-down needless to say I want to take the truck home with me so I can have it all to myself.

So much has been written about these guys, but I must add to the praise because the waffles were just so darn delicious!  We got one of each type of waffle, with blueberries, strawberries and powered sugar on top.  Perfection!  On top of being melt in your mouth delicious, the guys who work at the truck are funny and so friendly!

You think,  how very new yorker it is to have a food truck exclusively dedicated to waffles? You and your compatriots snub buffoons who hunker in line for the breakfast now dessert now metropolitan snack praised by foodies and flagrant drunk friday party goers alike. Then, you get the Brussels Wafel... say everytime you are in west village or central park,  which we all know is more often than we care to admit. Spekuloos haunts you.  Spekuloos whispers your name.  Spek--uuuu-looosss the voice lingers. The crispy caramelized waffle exterior swims in the stuff.  You add strawberries or banana, alternating respectively. You perk up when you see  your name scribbled on the yellow cardboard container.  This is what you've become now. They always serve you knowing your fix can be quelled in spurts. They'll smile and you'll smile back with a guarantee that you are a waffle or shall i say, wafel lover.  This teaches anyone to mock a craving this expensive and ludicrously yummy. Listen to the calls of spekuloos. You can't turn back now.

The smell of waffles from this little yellow truck will be good enough to make you stop for at least a second to see what's going on! Yup, just like that, I tried my first wafels and dinges!They have a special spread called Spekuloos & also Spekuloos flavor ICE CREAM! yummmm! And with all the other toppings, how can you possibly go wrong?!? :) I also tried the waffles with their beer ice cream and that was quite delicious as well--you could actually taste a good amount of the beer which was a good balance to the sweet waffle/chocolate :)So far, I saw these trucks at St.Marks, Columbus Circle and on Broadway near Columbia, but check their schedule on their website if you're planning to go find it.

I'm impressed by Wafles and Dinges. If I ever spot their bright yellow truck in the city, I'm ready to drop everything for a taste of the waffle with chocolate and strawberry. Or maybe some ice-cream?! Oh wait, I want the nutella as well. My first visit to them was in the West Village around midnight. The 2 guys who run the truck are extremely friendly and my friends and I stuck up quite a conversation with them. So much that, we even got a discount on our last waffle.
