YUM YUM YUM! follow these guys on twitter (waffletruck) for free dinges (always fun to see what kind of password they come up with)!

Try the spekuloos spread! I was going to go straight for the chocolate, but was persuaded by my friendly server to get spekuloos on half my wafel... and it was heaven.  I dream about it now.  siiighhhh

Yuck.  I used to be a fan of the Wafel Cart when the Wafels were fresh.  Today, I went to the one on Wall Street and was sorely disappointed.  The Wafels were pre-made and simply heated up.  That would be fine if it tasted good, but the problem was that the wafel tasted like non-stick cooking spray and old and soggy...like day-old french fries.  They were also stingy with the one topping (chocolate sauce).  I've had better wafels from a diner.

Ah, Wafels & Dinges. Or as it's affectionately known at my job, "The Waffle Truck." The Waffle Truck started off as a myth. We didn't know we could track it's location through the website, we didn't even know it's true name. We only knew that one of our coworkers had seen it on Park Avenue once, but by the time anyone went back out to look it was gone. Then, one glorious day this past fall, we found the right time and place for the Waffle Truck and indulged in some delicious waffles. Each time, I've had the 'liege' wafel, first with caramel and chocolate and the second time with pulled pork. The pulled pork/waffle combo is great, but they go a little heavy on the BBQ sauce. Otherwise, delicious. Best food I've had off a truck.

I have been trying to track this truck down for the past 2 weeks so was pretty excited when I found out they were only a block away from my work. To be quite honest, when I saw the location on twitter I grabbed my purse and bolted out the elevator in fear they were going to drive off.  I calmed down once I got there. It's a cute little truck with music playing, they seem like they're having a good time. I got the Liege with whip cream and it was YUMMY! It's soft , chewy and not too sweet. This is more like a dessert waffle as oppose to the one's you would eat for breakfast.  I am definatley a fan!
The liege waffle, in my limited experience, was good. However, who puts on salted butter on a sweet waffle?!

So right before the moment of my death this will be my last request. I come from jersey just to have this and it's always worth the trip. I get the liege waffle with ice cream chocolate syrup strawberries and bananas. You haven't lived if you haven't had one of these!!

When this truck comes to 46 & 6th ave - its a holiday!Waffles are not premade - they make it on the spot so you have to wait 5-10 minutes. The chocolate is very thick and very belgian!Ultimate Nirvana Experience!Highly recommended!

My friends and I walked over mile for these waffles. We looked up the truck info online and it said the truck would be at 7th Ave & Christopher St. When we got there the guy told us the truck broke down and it wasn't going to be fixed anytime soon. So our other option was to go all the way to St Mark's place between 2nd and 3rd Ave. We were so excited about trying these waffles that we just decided to go all the way to St. Marks. And of course after all that walking when we finally got there there were about 30 people standing in front of us. By this time one of my friends just wanted to go somewhere else but I had to try these waffles after everything we went through just to get there. And boy was it all worth it. I got the WMD (Weapons of Mass Destruction) with everything imaginable. The speculoos spread was hands down one of the best things I've ever tasted. So much better than nutella. The guy made a suggestion that the speculoos spread and dulce de leche would be too sweet and I'm glad  I listened because my waffle was the perfect amount of sweetness. I had the Belgian waffle and my friend tried the liege waffle, which I think i would prefer because it was soft and chewy. There's always next time.

Saw it on Bobby Flay's Challenge so I made a point to try it when my brother was in town. Simply amazing. Liege waffles are like cake. Their spekuloos is ginger-bread nutella-like spread sent from heaven.

Probably the best iced coffee I've ever had. I know you're thinking, 'how can iced coffee be that good?' because with every sip I took I asked myself the same thing. It was like a mixture of the best chocolate milk you've ever had with some of the best coffee. I look for it constantly on the streets.

keep lookin' for a yellow truck, you'll love the liege wafel from belgium. we are glad that belgians have invaded the gotham city but buy beware, they are expensive. they are worth like a gourmet pizza slice. bring $5 for a wafel - this includes one dinge or topping or if you have $3, go for mini-wafelini, a small wafelete with slices of banana & strawberries on a stick. don't worry the menu is not foreign - you'll get used to reading like: coupe dame blanche. it will satisfy you; it's an anytime snack. i had the wafel both ways light n' crisp and the original which i like better. don't chase the truck, it leaves at about 4:30 PM and probably sold out.

I noticed that these guys have a stand at Madison Square Park Market going on right now, so I had to pay them a visit since it's been a year or two since my last treat of theirs.  I got the liege waffle with belgian chocolate topping.  It was tasty but the only reason I didn't get more toppings is because at the time, I didn't want to spend too much money on a piece of waffle. Maybe I need to go all out with the toppings one day? Overall, good but not over the top amazing.  It will definitely satisfy your fix for a warm bread-y dessert with melted toppings, that's for sure. The people are very friendly and cool, and when I first saw their stand at the Brooklyn flea market a couple years ago, I bought the cutest Nutella spread knife from them.
Wafels and Dinges was the highlight of my trip to New York!  I wish I had could have gone here at least once more.
Thomas the Waffle Guy himself challenged my last post of 2 stars and invited me to go back and taste the new and improved Brussels... so here's the conclusion: For more reviews visit my blog.

Monday has become my favorite day of the week because the Wafel and Dinges truck comes up to Columbia University! I have recently discovered the deliciousness of a Brussels waffle with speculoos, strawberries, bananas, walnuts, and whipped cream. What a foodgasm!
my mom makes the meanest waffles ever but this somehow tops it. such a cool idea, to deliver waffles on a freakin truck!? genius. best and most delicious waffle ive ever had. GO THEM.

"Damn, that's cold", is probably an common response to my reviews.  I hate it when people see some story about some NYC  joint on Food Network and say in a robotic tone, "I must go now, the mother ship commands it" and then regardless of how bad it is say it's "too die for".Well,  Wafels and Dinges is one place worth the praise.  The Liege waffle with spekuloos (a graham cracker spread) is like sex on a plate(ok, since it is a food cart its like sex on a piece of paper with plastic utensils).  The waffle is soft with a nice crisp exterior - definitaly not like Eggo's and the spread is unbelievable.Although expensive at $5, I love walking past the UES places that are dying only because people  are tired of ordering a simple crepe for $14 in a restaurant.

Hands down the best food truck in Manhattan.  I really don't think there is anything better you can get from a food truck than a waffle from the truck.  My favorite (and only) is the Throwdown Waffle, which is the waffle that was featured on Throwdown with Bobby Flay.  Pretty sure it's also been featured on Food Network's The Best Thing I Ever Ate.  Not something you want to eat every day, but a splurge now and then is good for your soul.  The Throwdown Waffle is made with a warm delicious waffle topped with whipped cream and the spekuloos spread that is a nutella like gingerbread cookie spread (sans chocolate and hazelnuts).  They sell the spekuloos spread by the jar and I brought some to my family over the holidays to spread on a homemade waffle and it was just as delicious.  I always take visitors to this truck as a New York City must have food.

Best waffles ever! My co-worker introduced me to this truck and I am big fan of it ever since. Good thing is they are in Wall Street only on Wednesdays, so it's just a week thing otherwise I couldn't restrict myself from having this piece of heaven... it's so delicious.
Had their signature waffle at the Union Square holiday market. Best. Waffle. Ever. Run, don't walk there.

A little bit pricey, but at least you get a free topping. I got the liège wafel w/ the special Belgian sauce (not mayo!) and it was delicious! It looks like peanut butter, but I think it's some other kind of nut. I wouldn't get one with the works, because it would take away from their texture and how sweet they are. I wish they were a little warmer, but it was freezing outside, so any warmth is better than nothing. Anytime I see this truck, I'll have to get a wafel!

i spontaneously blurted out "Holy SH*T!" as i took my first bite into a brussels style wafel topped with spekuloos and fresh strawberries - because it was just that darn delicious!the wafel is light and crispy (just like they said it would be) and the spekuloos spread, which is like a nutty, sweet spread (think the consistency of peanut butter but tastes way better) was one of the most amazing things i've ever tasted. i literally could take a spoon and eat a jar of this stuff, it's that yummy.the fresh strawberries were a nice compliment to the waffle and spekuloos, helping to cut some of the sweetness as well.the only thing i would have liked is if my wafel was warmer but regardless it was still delicious.

Solidly delicious 4.5 stars. I usually get the WMD (wafels of mass deliciousness) which gets me as many toppings as I want, making me a happy camper. I will say to stay away from the speculous (sp?) topping - did not like the taste. It's super sweet if you get the fudge and caramel but so worth it. When you walk down the street carrying a wafel piled high with toppings and whipped cream, you will be the subject of many deservedly envious stares.

The best "food on wheels" in the city.  OK, maybe I should qualify that with best "desserts / snacks on wheels".  I feel so lucky and fortunate to work near one of their regular locations (52nd between Sixth and Seventh), and given that it's their Friday spot, it makes for a terrific way to end the work week.  I tend to stick with the Brussels Wafel, light and crispy, made to perfection, with maple syrup and either Nutella, whipped cream, or spekuloos.  If you've never had spekuloos, don't let the weird name frighten you.  Go for it.  That sh*t is another awesome import from Europe.  Like a graham cracker spread.  So glad it's available in a jar now from the truck, but yeah, it's a bit expensive, yet worth it.  While very tantilizing, I've yet to try their bacon and syrup and pulled pork wafel.  Maybe for lunch one day.  The Liege wafel is a bit different from the standard American style waffle (which for some reason is the Brussels Wafel), but worthy of a try, too.  Slightly on the chewy side relative to the Brussels, with sugar pellets that are like little sweet surprises in every bite.  The staff working the truck is always friendly, too.

Watched Bob Flay on the Food Network do a throw down with the owner of Wafels & Dinges so decided to go.  Using the website I found they were in the West Village where I was having dinner. For dessert I went there and got the liege wafel with the graham cracker spread, whipped cream, bananas, strawberrys and hot fudge.  I was disappointed that the waffle wasn't cooked fresh...they just warmed one up. Loved everything else however. Defintely worth a visit.

gahh maybe i didn't get the combination. i got their wafel with speculoo sauce only. it wasn't amazing. i guess i also had quite high expectations of this place after reading all of the reviews/raves. however, i guess it's just a food truck. i was not very impresssed. i have to admit, though, that the people were super friendly!

I don't think anyone needs convincing when it comes to visiting the Wafels & Dinges truck; I can't really imagine the person who wouldn't want to try a Belgian-style waffle made fresh before their eyes.  So I guess this review is mostly about reliving the experience, trying to hold on to the feeling of spontaneity and deliciousness that came with my wafel...I had heard about Wafels & Dinges, and had seen the truck around the city and even on television, in an episode of "Throwdown with Bobby Flay" (spoiler alert: Wafels & Dinges won!)  On the show, the truck's owner was so enthusiastically passionate about his wafels, that I thought they must be something special, and I couldn't wait to try them.Then today, while walking around Brooklyn with no specific destination, I happened upon the truck, like a bright-yellow beacon of good things to come.  What a great feeling- to find something you forgot you were looking for, when you weren't expecting to find it.I tried the Liege wafel.  At first, I thought I would be a purist and try it plain.   I did, for a few bites, and it was delicious.  It was so good, in fact, that it made me wonder if I was missing out by not trying their other concoctions-- the 'dinges'.  One of the super-friendly wafel-makers gave me some speculoos to try.  It was beyond delicious; the combination was warm, indulgent, distinctive, satisfying.  And the wafel-makers working in the truck were friendly, funny, and seemed to be genuinely enthusiastic about serving wafels to the hungry and excited customers who kept coming up to the truck.  What can I say?  I'm a convert.  Life seems a little sweeter, in a way that it didn't a few hours ago.   I can't wait to happen upon this truck again.

There is no other pick me up quite like a lieges wafel with spekuloos and vanilla ice cream. Add some strawberries for an even tastier treat. Spekuloos on a wafel is so ridiculously good that I got everyone at my job on the wafels and dinges bandwagon. Even when I'm trying to eat healthy, there's always room for a waffle.

After my Halloween plans fell through, I decided to take a walk around Union Square and look at the costumes anyway.  But tired from the day, I decided to just head home and found my way to Astor Place.  And then, right before the subway station was Wafels & Dinges.  I LOVE BELGIAN WAFFLES and there is no way I could pass this truck without at least sampling their product.  Therefore I ordered a Liege (the more denser belgian waffle) with some powdered sugar.  Yummy!  Oh how I wish I always knew where Chief Wafel Master Thomas Degeest everyday in my life.  But then again that's probably a good thing 'cause I would most definitely be putty in his hand just for one of his creations.

The Liege wafels are my favorite.  They're already sweet so I just get them with a little sprinkling of powdered sugar.  These wafels are worth seeking out.  I had one just before I left for the holidays and spent the next two weeks craving another one.

So pictures this, a week ago I was out for a nice afternoon walk near the great lawn in central park. I see many people gather around a cart. I wonder what it is and its Wafels and Dinges. Sadly, I didn't have any money, however just smelling it made me want one. So today I was walking in that same area and the cart was still there and I just happen to bring my wallet. So after waiting for 2 minutes, I decided to try the daily special waffle, wafel de smores. It was a waffle with spekuloos, belgian chocolate, and marshmallows. So waiting for it, the smell engulfs the great lawn area of the park. people float there, sort of like the cartoons. i got my waffle and walked to the nearest bench, it wasn't gonna be neat if I ate it standing up. I cut my first bite, it had all of the elements. the waffle , spekuloos, chocolate, and marshmallow. I opened my mouth and automatically my life changed. It was sweet from the chocolate, savory from the waffle, and a little bit sweeter with the spekuloos. That SAUCE is INCREDIBLE. I don't know what it was, peanut buttery, caramelesque. I don't know. Each bite was better than the last, especially the one with all the elements. When it was over, I was sad. It was literally one of the best things I have ever eaten. I can not wait to go back, except I will weigh 5000 pounds if i continually go back.
This place is great. They have two kinds of waffles and plenty of different toppings. It's a great snack or desert, but not a full meal.
I've had waffles in Belgium and this place was way better.  Didn't have it out the truck but luckly they had a booth in Union Sq. Park.  I knew I should have bought a jar of the Spekuloos spread!

Here in Philly's University City, truck vendors are stationed around every corner. Still, when my friend and I recently visited the wafel truck in NYC, we immediately fell in love.I'm not just talking about the melt-in-your-mouth, delicious waffles, either; we loved the friendly people inside the truck, too! So much so, in fact, that they even managed to convince us to try the spekuloos--you know, that hot new Belgian graham cracker spread.If you're in the city, just look up the wafel truck's location for the day and go have yourself a true NYC experience.

I had the belgian wafel - VERY light and crispy made fresh off the waffle grill exclusively for moi on a cold winter night.  So good!  However, I had just come back from the opera, and not wanting to pay what, $7 for a chocolate bar, and I was FAMISHED.  When I stepped off the subway, I smelled the delicious aroma coming from the wafels & dinges cart!  I stood there, not wanting to pay $4 for a wafel, but I am a sucker for a friendly hello and informative nicely designed menus.  I devoured the waffle as soon as I got home.  It would have tasted better with some maple syrup, I just had it plain with a sprinkle of powdered sugar.  It was nice and light and crispy just as the wafel guy said, but I don't know if it was worth $4.  I don't think I can replicate the lightness and crispiness myself though.
Amazing! Seriously thought about walking back to the truck for a second helping.

Love, love, LOVE! Wafles and Dinges is outside my job in Park Slope on Saturdays and it's now my Saturday traditional to get a waffle...I look forward to Saturdays every week! The waffles are absolutely delish and reasonably priced. What more can you ask for?!

You can get a belgium waffle with everything on it (strawberries, whipped cream, nuttela, chocolate syrup, SUGAR) for $7.  A bundle of deliciousness.  Only negative is that there's nowhere to sit nearby.  I just wolfed mine down by the side of the truck.

wow.  really great after dinner dessert truck, you just have to find out where they are (since they're mobile) and then make sure you're in their near vicinity.  "the spread" is nutella-like but WAY way better, liked a graham cracker spread, but even that doesn't give it justice.  If this place was parked outside my work place, i'd be 20 lbs heavier by the end of the year.  yummy stuff, check it out and you'll be hooked.

The visit to the Wafel and Dinges truck really made my Saturday afternoon. First of all it was going to rain this Saturday, but since it didn't me and my friend decided to stroll around Park Slope actually in search of a treat like a cup cake! We walked by the truck and the bright yellow really stop us! Cupcake-What? frogetaboudit! I traded it for a Wafel instead! And I am so happy I made the choice-and by the way I did split it with my friend. It was super warm...Our dinges of choice..belgian hot chocolate fudge and whipped cream!YUMMMMMMM Definitely a perfect treat for a Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn!

wafels and dinges, oh boyi assume this means waffles and toppings??anyway, it was parked across the street from madison square park this morning and i was curious.i think its kind of a rip-off that its a dollar per topping... but the breakfast special is a good deal$5 for a wafel, one dinge and choice of coffee or oji had a cinnamon liege and i couldnt decide between belgian chocolate or dulce de leche. the nice wafel lady gave me both!

We spent three full days in New York eating at a different place every day but this is the place that all 8 of us remember the most (in a good way) -- all 8 of us... I think that says it all... They should sell t-shirts that say "I am a speckulos believer" or something....

So if you want to order the good stuff at this truck, you should probably know how to say what you want.  I obviously didn't and when I ordered the guy laughed.. both times.. :) hahaha  I had a liege wafel (the guy told me twice how to pronounce it, I still can't get it) with spekuloos spread (he totally laughed at this one).  There were two guys in the truck, one making the wafel and the other making the spread.  The other guy kept chatting with me and was very friendly.. It was an awkward conversation cuz I couldn't hear much of what he was saying so the other guy had to translate.  But anyways, onto the food, the wafel was not bad.  It wasn't as good as the one I had at Waterzooi this past week and I think I was slightly turned off by the spekuloos spread.  It was good but I don't think it's something I would prefer to get again.  I guess I'm not that big on nutella. =X  Next time, I'm sticking to ice cream!!! :)  btw, they opened a permanent cart right by the Gap at South Street Seaport.. :)
I got the Liege with strawberries... it was SOOOO GOOD!!! I want to try the Spekuloos next but the liege is delicious on its own.  Plus, the workers were super nice.

I've seen these guys for a while now and finally gave it a shot today for breakfast. They are down here in the financial district where I work all of the time, you can follow them on Facebook and Twitter I believe. Tried a waffle with bananas and Nutella. So good I tell, you, next time I'm going to do strawberries and ice cream.

AMAZING, delicious, and fun dessert spot! Call the number listed on yelp and listen to the recording to find the one closest to you. The waffle had an awesome texture and the toppings are fresh and delicious.

I've had a hankering for wafels and ice cream, but I don't do lines.  Saturday at the Parked! Food Truck Festival I braved the winding line of bodies and waited to order one of the many varieties of wafels this truck offers!  I decided to go for the liege wafel with vanilla ice cream and nutella.  After the first bite, I realized the wait was worth it!  It wasn't chewy sweet deliciousness, but rather RIDICULOUS chewy sweet deliciousness!  Plus the friendly guys working the truck made the waiting experience all the more bearable!  Definitely chase this truck!

went to NY on a trip. ended up at wafels & dinges and experienced a trip. holy shit, waffles, ice cream, SPECULOOS SPREAD (the best), fudge, and a few others i cant remember, an orgy of fantastic flavors in my mouth :].

To be honest, I was a little disappointed with the "amazing" Spekuloos sauce but I think it was because it was SO hyped up. It wasn't bad and I ate my entire waffle with Spekuloos and strawberries. Next time I'll try the chewy waffle with Dulce de Leche instead. My brother had the "works" waffle with ice cream and several toppings and said it was a bit much. So I'd recommend simpler combinations, unless you're feeling indulgent. I'll definitely be back. The guys making my waffle were incredibly friendly, chatty.
yum i loved the spread. i bought a jar. the waffle with the spread was so good. my friend even got a jar herself.  the man behind the counter was super friendly. haha 6.99 for a jar of spread. funny.

This truck smells great as you walk by.....I stopped and checked out the sign and thought I'd give it a try. The waffles was yummy, but they are way too expensive. $5 for a waffle with one topping and then a $1 for each additional topping...I tried just one topping (which they kind of skimmed me on) and realized you need more then one topping to make the waffle not taste plain. It was tasty but again a tad on the pricey side if you ask me!

Not bad - could be great. But they served a cold waffle. They just re-heated a dry, cold waffle and put a [very] little chocolate and [very] few slices of banana. Nothing exciting. Edible but not what I expected given the hype.

mmmmm.... wafles.... mmmm..... sweet sweet dinges..... (pronounced- Ding-eeze)if you are looking for an afternoon sugar high chaulk full of super sweetness.... call the wafles & dinges hotline and get yourself to the corner of the day.... 3 kinds of wafles and about 8 different dinges (toppings - which they are very generous with).... have the secret word of the day and some dinges are free.... (do your research...)they offer bibs if you ask nicely.... if your up for a challange, go with out... must stop reviewing... second wave sugar coma setting in....

Stopped by the truck parked by Astor Place last week.  Based on reviews, we tried a liege waffle topped with spekuloos and strawberries.  The waffle was warm with a crisp exterior and soft, warm interior, just the way a waffle should be.  Everything combined resulted in a treat that was a little too sweet for me (and I have a pretty significant sweet tooth), and the prices were a little high for what you get.  That said, it's a nice addition to the food truck craze and their employees were extremely friendly.  They also have a stationary stand at South St Seaport in case you don't want to hunt the truck down.

I think 3.25 stars is a more fair evaluation from my experience, but since that is not possible, I will rate it 3 stars.  I had a Livingsocial deal for one savory waffle, one dessert waffle, and a drink.  Since the deal is only good for the truck, I checked out the website and went over to the 52nd St/7th Ave location.  Unexpectedly, I only saw a cart there.  When I showed them my Livingsocial deal, they apologized and said that the truck is actually on 49th St/3rd Ave.  I told them that the website said otherwise and was told that I should have checked twitter or Facebook.  Great, except that I can't access either site at work.  Plus, the Wafels & Dinges location webpage did not mention that their truck has capricious mind and that I need to check other websites.  This instantly put me in a bad mood.I thought about asking for a refund on the deal, but decided to just go to the other location so I can give a fair review.  The truck was where they said it would be.  And the two truck employees were very friendly, cheerful, and helpful despite my sourness.  So kudos on that, Wafels & Dinges!  I was also informed by one of the truck employees that the reason the truck couldn't be at the 52nd St. location as advertised is because some diplomats were meeting there or something so that the truck couldn't park there.  This is an excuse I can live with, but still minus 0.75 star for unhelpful employees at the cart.Now for the actual food.  I got the pulled pork wafel, hot cocoa, and liege wafel with strawberries, chocolate fudge, whipped cream, and powdered sugar (at least, those are the components that I could make out).  As a note, I asked for recommendations on the dessert waffle and was told that liege wafel is a better choice for dessert.  I then asked for whatever classic topping for the liege wafel.  Pulled pork wafel was decent and the pickle was yummy.  However, the balance of flavor/texture of wafel and pork was really off.  Pulled pork had a very strong flavor and the soggy wafel did not add any positive flavor or texture to it.  Hot cocoa was alright.  I expected a stronger chocolate flavor, but at least it wasn't overly sweet.  As for the liege wafel dessert, I was somewhat disappointed, albeit it's mostly my fault for not specifying my order.  I prefer simple, not too sweet desserts and this wafel was completely covered in sweet, sweet, and more sweet with a bit of tartness from the strawberries.  I cannot comment accurately on the taste of the wafel itself, but after scraping some toppings off, I thought it tasted not too bad.  I couldn't detect the sugary crispiness very well, but I think it was there.   Pretty decent overall but not superb...  so minus 1 star.

Spekuloos, nutella, and strawberries on a 'wafel'...wow! I went to the truck for the first time this Sunday. I need to work out more, because a new weekend tradition has just been born. And, no, I don't think I can ever have a waffle from anywhere else ever again.

Bacon waffle: the most scrumptious thing I've eaten this year. Spekuloos spread: the oddest thing I've eaten this year. Tastes like graham crackers -- terrible idea on paper, delicious in practice. The staff on the truck answered all my questions patiently and did a great job.

this 'wafel' was lovely, crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside and perfectly cooked!  i want to say that it was better than what i had tasted at petite abeille, though that had been almost a year ago.  it's probably because it (tasted like it) was made from wheat flour?  i think the dough could have been less sweet, but i suppose that's personal preference.  the wafel was nice with or without 'dinges.'
A guy with a cart who makes awesome waffles.  Find him if you can.
OMG THE BELGIAN FUDGE SAUCE!  I would inject it straight into my veins if I could.
We saw the Bobby Flay epsiode and had to find one of these carts....the waffles were delicious. A little pricey but the family did not leave one crumb.
Scrap the gym, my new new years resolution will be hitting up pomme frites + vol de nuit + waffles & dinges all in 1 night. And maybe become a beer brewing monk in Belgium.

The wafel truck probably doesn't need any more reviews, but it is one of my favorite things in the city.  It is up by Columbia on Mondays.  Depending on the toppings you get, it is a great breakfast/brunch (maple syrup, walnuts, bananas), or a fabulous afternoon treat (chocolate, strawberries, bananas, whipped cream)!

En route to the Dessert Truck, I stumbled across the Wafels truck... quite a conundrum. Not really. I did both. Had the Liege Cinnamon Royale which smelled amazing on its own but at the suggestion of the truck guy, I opted for adding whipped cream and strawberries, which I now realize was a total upsell (I'm such a sucker). So I would highly advise against this. The berries do absolutely nothing for the cinnamoney deliciousness, if not get it a bit soggy. Next time I'm going for just the dusting of sugar. Save the two bucks for the Dessert Truck.

Upon exiting the Trader Joe's in Union Square the other day, I was intrigued by this brightly colored trucks labeled "Wafels and Dinges." Loving myself some waffles, but on a  one-week no dessert ban, I decided to have a cup of coffee instead (also, since it was a windy 30 degree day).Can I just tell you, this cup of coffee was one of the most fabulous cups I've ever had. Each mouthful was so complex and favorful....so dense and rich. Absolutely delicious. I only wish the Wafels truck was on my way to work :-(

I would love to give Wafels & Dinges 5 stars but they're just so inconvenient with their mobility, also it can get pretty packed and the service can get slow. Despite all that, their waffles are SO DAMN GOOD, especially the "de bacon + syrup wafel". It has bacon, enuff said, haha. Seriously though I didn't know waffles could be so interesting before this place, they offer so many different varieties.Oh and their hot chocolate is to die for, I mean it.  Even if you're one of those people who always gets the same thing, take a look at their menu from time to time. It's wittiness never fails to amuse me. So, do I like their dinges? Yes, yes I do like their dinges.
